title: 113_s307
content:
The Seventy-ninth Congress regulations allow for the deduction of intangible drilling and development costs for geothermal deposits similar to oil and gas wells. However, this exclusion does not apply to major integrated oil companies. The amendment allows deductions for intangible drilling and development costs over a 60-month period starting from the month of payment. This amendment applies to expenses incurred after December 31, 2013. SEC. 104 limits the percentage depletion allowance for oil and gas wells for major integrated oil companies. The allowance shall be zero for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2013. SEC. 105 limits the deduction for tertiary injectants. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exclude major integrated oil companies from certain deductions, with the amount not deductible allowed to be spread over a 60-month period. This amendment applies to expenses incurred after December 31, 2013. SEC. 106. MODIFICATION OF DEFINITION OF MAJOR INTEGRATED OIL COMPANY. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include successors in interest of major integrated oil companies. If a successor controls over 50% of crude oil or natural gas production, they are considered a major integrated oil company. Conforming amendments are made to ensure consistency in the definition. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include successors in interest of major integrated oil companies. The amendments made in this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2013, regarding the application of certain clauses related to taxable years tested. TITLE II--OUTER CONTINENTAL SHELF OIL AND NATURAL GAS

Repeal of Outer Continental Shelf deep water and deep gas royalty relief. The Secretary of the Interior is no longer required to provide royalty relief in lease sale terms starting from the first lease sale after the enactment of this Act.

TITLE III--MISCELLANEOUS

Deficit reduction. TITLE III--MISCELLANEOUS

SEC. 301. DEFICIT REDUCTION.

Savings from this Act will be used for deficit reduction or reducing the Federal debt as deemed appropriate by the Secretary of the Treasury.

SEC. 302. BUDGETARY EFFECTS.

The budgetary effects of this Act will be determined in compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010.
